semantic_title: Coding Drug and Alcohol Interactions as Poisoning
section_path: Section I > C. Chapter-Specific Coding Guidelines > 19. Chapter 19: Injury, poisoning, and certain other consequences of external causes > e. Adverse Effects, Poisoning, Underdosing and Toxic Effects > (iv) Interaction of drug(s) and alcohol

content.full_text: When a reaction results from the interaction of a drug(s) and alcohol, this would be classified as poisoning. See Section I.C.4. if poisoning is the result of insulin pump malfunctions. For Sequela (Late Effects) see Section I.B.10. (Evidence: pg no: 84, L6-L7)
content.summary: Drug and alcohol interactions are classified as poisoning (Evidence: pg no: 84, L6-L7)
key_concepts: Drug and alcohol interaction (Evidence: pg no: 84, L6)
Insulin pump malfunction exception (Evidence: pg no: 84, L7)

detailed_rules.rule_text: When a reaction results from the interaction of a drug(s) and alcohol, this would be classified as poisoning (Evidence: pg no: 84, L6-L7)
detailed_rules.explanation: Any adverse reaction that occurs when drugs interact with alcohol must be coded as poisoning, regardless of whether the drug was properly prescribed (Evidence: pg no: 84, L6-L7)

workflow_steps: Step 1: Identify drug(s) involved in reaction
Step 3: Determine reaction resulted from drug-alcohol interaction
Step 4: Code as poisoning using appropriate T36-T50 code

code_ranges.description: Poisoning by, adverse effects of and underdosing of drugs, medicaments and biological substances (Evidence: pg no: 84, L6-L7)
usage_rules: Apply when reaction results from drug and alcohol interaction (Evidence: pg no: 84, L6-L7)

references_to.title: Insulin pump malfunction poisoning
references_to.explanation: Referenced for insulin pump malfunction cases (Evidence: pg no: 84, L7)

references_to.title: Sequela (Late Effects)
references_to.explanation: Referenced for coding late effects of drug-alcohol poisoning (Evidence: pg no: 84, L7)

coding_scenarios.scenario: Patient on prescribed benzodiazepine develops respiratory depression after consuming alcohol
coding_scenarios.documentation_example: Patient taking prescribed lorazepam developed respiratory depression after drinking alcohol at dinner
step_by_step: Step 1: Identify lorazepam as prescribed medication
Step 3: Recognize respiratory depression as result of drug-alcohol interaction
Step 4: Code as poisoning due to drug-alcohol interaction

correct_coding.sequencing: Poisoning code first, followed by manifestation
correct_coding.rationale: Drug-alcohol interactions are classified as poisoning (Evidence: pg no: 84, L6-L7)

incorrect_coding.rationale: Would be incorrect to use adverse effect code when alcohol is involved
incorrect_coding.common_mistake: Coding as adverse effect instead of poisoning

warnings: Always code drug-alcohol interactions as poisoning, not adverse effects (Evidence: pg no: 84, L6-L7)
best_practices: Document both drug and alcohol involvement clearly (Evidence: pg no: 84, L6-L7)
common_mistakes: Coding drug-alcohol interactions as adverse effects (Evidence: pg no: 84, L6-L7)
tips: Check for insulin pump malfunctions requiring different coding approach (Evidence: pg no: 84, L7)
implementation_notes: Requires documentation of both substances involved in interaction
clinical_context: Common with CNS depressants and alcohol
